field_edited_text.value:
2. expanding educational opportunities
and public involvement,

3. increasing recreational opportunities
and public involvement,

4. improving water quality and wildlife
habitat in concert with the Fish and
Wildlife Commission, and,

5. identifying special projects for the
harbor.

B.O.B., which has representatives from City,
State, and Federal agencies, members of
conservation groups, port industry, and the
private sector began work in the summer
of 1984 and has identified a number of
projects to be pursued in 1985-8nd beyond.
These include a specific clean-up program
for the shoreline of the harbor extending
from Ft. McHenry/Lazaretto Point into the
Inner Harbor, endorsement and support for
the Water Resources Educational Center
Middle Branch, development of the Canton
Waterfront Park, working with the Park
Board on improvements to Fort Smallwood,
an active role in support of the City’s
Marina Master Plan, and involvement in
Harbor Expo ’'85.

Marina Master Plan -

Baltimore’s harbor is one of the largest and
most active ports in the country. Over three
thousand commercial vessels call on the
port each year. The introduction of a new
water activity, recreational boating, in a
largely commercial port has raised a number
of concerns regarding congestion, boating
safety, and the standards by which marinas
and other support facilities are developed.
For many years zoning regulations allowed
marinas to develop virtually anywhere along
the shoreline even adjacent to active port
facilities.

The City understands that it is important to
have guidelines for marina development in
order to maintain safety, to support City
redevelopment efforts, and to minimize
impacts on commercial port operations.

Two actions were taken in early 1985 to
address the issue of the safe development
of marinas in the harbor. The first, a Marina
Master Plan was approved by the Planning
Commission. All marina proposals must be
consistent with the master plan. Secondly,
the Mayor and City Council enacted
changes in the Zoning Code which made.
marinas conditional uses in all zoning
districts. Marina proposals must be reviewed
by the Board of Municipal Zoning and
Appeals.

These two actions are important steps
toward keeping the harbor viable for
commercial shipping and providing

opportunities for recreational boating.

Baltimore Harbor Expo ’85 -

The City of Baltimore and much of the State
of Maryland have looked to Baltimore’s
harbor for over 250 years for employment,
housing, recreational activities, and as a tie
to the rest of the world. To celebrate Balti-
more City’s bond with the harbor and the
Chesapeake Bay, Harbor Expo ’85 has been
planned for August 2nd - August 4th, 1985.

Harbor Expo ’85 will focus on the diversity
of the roles that Baltimore’s harbor plays in
the City, State, and nation. Special events
will highlight the Port’s shipping and
manufacturing interests with tours of the
industrial shoreline and visits to marine |
terminals. Citizens will learn of the harbor
and bay’s ecological and natural resources
through two days of Baysic Training, with
courses ranging from testing water quality
to fishing to crabbing and environmental
awareness. Fishing tournaments, crew row-
ing, boating regattas, and waterfront picnics
will reintroduce the public to the harbor’s
sports and recreational potential. Through-
out Harbor Expo ’85 special events, tours,
and activities will provide a unique insight
to Baltimore’s harbor for residents and
visitors. It is anticipated that Harbor Expo
will become an annual celebration.

Baltimore Harbor Endowment -
Created in 1985 initially to support Harbor
Expo '85, the Baltimore Harbor Endowment,
is a non-profit organization which will fund
a variety of programs and projects to
expand the public’s knowledge and use of
the harbor. Directed by the Bay Opportuni-
ties for Baltimore committee, the Baltimore
Harbor Endowment, will provide ongoing
support for Harbor Expo and allow the
private sector to financially support
iImprovements to water quality, public
access projects, and educational programs.

The above programs represent a major
expansion of the resources of Baltimore’s
harbor available to the public. Coupled with
an aggressive port community, economic
development, and new residential and
commercial projects, the water’s edge, the
harbor, and the Chesapeake Bay present a
diversity of opportunities few cities and
states have. Our challenge is to work with
these resources, to develop them carefully _
and with wisdom, and to pass them on to &=
new generations. =
